awd_titl_txt: TC: Medium: Collaborative Research: WHISPER - Wireless, Handheld, Infrastructureless, Secure Communication System for the Prevention of Eavesdropping and Reprisal
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the design of an infrastructureless
communication system that makes it easy for people without expertise
in computer security to safely communicate with friends and family
members without being subjected to third-party surveillance,
censorship, propaganda, or reprisal.  The primary goals of this work
are to (1) further open access to information people require to
educate themselves and (2) make sharing information easier.
Particular attention is paid to designing protocols that do not rely
on centralized control points, which are subject to attack.  The
influence of patterns in human behavior on communication system
performance, energy efficiency, and security are being studied, and
the findings used to guide the development of better, user-aware,
communication protocols.  Design and analysis of communication
protocols; defenses against side-channel attacks on portable
communication devices; distributed system architecture; and
energy-efficient software systems play central roles in the work.

This project took two independent paths, one led by the PI and one led by the co-PI.

----
From the PI.

The Internet was once credited with broadening access to information, and the ability to share it.  However, this consensus has been changing over time.

``The Net interprets censorship as damage and routes around it.''
  - John Gilmore, 1993.

``I used to believe the Internet offered limitless opportunities for free speech; now I believe it is becoming a smorgasbord of opportunities for authoritarian control.''
  - Simon Davies, 1998.

There are now many examples of the Internet being used against free speech.  It is fundamentally an infrastructure-based and largely centralized structure that concentrates communication in a few locations, where it is susceptible to attack.

This project has focused on developing technology foundations allowing normal people to communicate freely, without being subject to blocking, censorship, or surveillance.  The key idea is using direct and transitive communication among commodity smartphones.  Instead of talking to a cellphone tower or a wireless access point, you talk directly with another phone.  And if you want to get your message across town, it hops from phone to phone until it reaches its destination.  But that approach is challenging, and opens many questions.

- How many people need to use the technology before your messages can reach the people you want to talk with?

- What happens if an attacker tries to trick you into thinking he is someone else?

- How can you stop spam and other network abuse when you don't trust anybody?

In this project, we pulled together a team of 15 students, most of them volunteers, to answer these questions and figure out whether it is practical to build a community network that will keep working even if someone pulls the plug on the Internet.  We learned a lot.

When only 0.2% of the students on a college campus used our research prototype application, messages reached 85% of users, with user motion helping to spread messages.  One of the big challenges to using decentralized wireless networks is that malicious users can pretend to be numerous normal users, something called a Sybil attack.  We developed a defense against Sybil attacks that works even when nobody in the network is trusted.  We also developed a way to use predictable human motion to get messages to users quickly and privately.

The project continues, thanks to volunteers and an NSF technology commercialization program.  If you are interested in becoming involved, please contact us (http://1am-networks.com/).
